In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Hee yaf nowt of the texte a pulled hen
That seyht that hvntteris be non holy men
Ne that a Mvnk whanne hee is Rechelees
Is likenid to a fychs that is waterles
This is to seye a Mvnk owt of his kloystre
But thilke texte heeld he nowght worht anoystre
And I seyde his opynioūn was goode
What scholde hee stodye and make hy self woode
Vppon a book alwey in kloystre to powre
Ore swinke wtith his handis and labovre
As Avstin bit how schall the world be servid
Late Avstin have his swynk to hym Reservid
Ther fore he was aprekesour a Ryght
Grehowndis hee hadde as swifte as fowll īnflyght
Of pꝰerkyngge ⁊ of hvnttyngge fore thee hare
Was all his laste for no cost wolde hee spare
¶ I sawe his slevis prrafiled atte thee hand
Wtith gryis ⁊ that thee fyneste in this land
And forto festene his hood vnder his chyn
Hee hadde of gold wrovght afull corious pyn
A loue knotte īn the grettere ende theer was
His his hed was balled that schon as any glas
And eke his face as hee hadde been ānnoynt
Hee was a lord full fat and in good poynt
His Eeyen stepe and Rollyngge in his hed
That stemede as the furneys of a leed
His botis sovple his hors in greet state
Now certeynlye hee was a feyir prralate
Hee nas nowt pale as a for peyned goost
A fat swan louede hee best of any Roost
His palfrey was as brown as is aberie
¶ A frere theer was a wantown ⁊ a merie
A limytur a full solempne man
In all the orderis foure is theer nōmn that can
So moche of daliavnce and feyir langage
Hee hadde maad full manye a Mariage
Of yonge wōmmen atte his owne cost
Vnto his ordre hee was a noble post
Full well be louid and famulier was hee
Wtith frankeleynis over all in his cvnttree
And wtith worthy wōmmen of the town
For hee hadde power offe confescioun
As hee seyde hym self more thanne a cvrat
Fore of his ordre he was licenciat
And full swetely herde hee confescioun
And plesavnt was in his abcelicioun
Hee was an esy man to yeven penawnce
There as hee wiste to have a good petavnce
For vnto a poure ordre forto yeve
It is sygne that a man is weell ischreve
For yif hee yaf hee durste make a vawnt
Hee wiste that a man was Repentawnt
For manye a man so hard is of his hertte
Hee may nowt wepe yif hym sore smertte
Therfore in stede of wepingge ⁊ preyeris
Men moste yeve selvir to the pore freris
His typet was ay farcid full of knivis
And pynnis forto yeve to feyre wivis
And certeynlie hee hadde a merie note
Well cowde hee syngge ⁊ pleyin on a Rote
Of yeddynggis hee baar witterly the pryis
His necke wyght was as the flowrdelyis
Therto hee was strong as a champiown
Hee knew well thee tavernis in every town
And every osteler and eke tapstere
Bettere thanne a lazer ore a beggere
For vnto swich a worthy man as hee
A cordede nowt as bee his facvltee
To haue wtith swiche sike lazeris a queyntavnce
Hit is nowt Oneste it may nowt a vavnce
Forto delyn whit swych simple porayle
But all wtith Riche and selleris offe vetayle
And overal theer as profyit scholde arrize
Curteys hee was and lovly of his servise
Theere ne was no man nowhere so vertewus
And hee was thee beste beggere īn all his hows
Fore thowgh a wedewe hadde nowt a scho
So plesawnt was his in principio
Yit wolde hee have a ferthyng ore hee wentte
His purchas was well bettere thane his Rent
And Rage hee cowde Ryghte as it were a whelp
In louedayis there cowde hee moche help
For there hee was nowt lyke a cloysterer
Wtith a thred bare kope as apoure skoler
But hee was lyik a Mayster ore pope
Of dowble worstede was his semely cope
That Rowndede as abelle owt of the presse
Svmwhat he lipsede for his wantownesse
To make his Englychs swete vppōm his tungge
And īn his harpyngge whanne that he hadde sungge
His Seyen tvinkelede in his hed a Ryght
As done the sterris in the frosty nyght
This worthy limytorur was klepid huberd
¶ A marchawnt theer was wtith a forked beerd
In Motle ⁊ heygh on horsse hee satte
Vppon his hed a flavndris bever hatte
His botis weren clapsyd feyre and fetisly
His Resounis hee speke full solempnely
Schewyngge alwey the enkres of his winnyngge
Hee wolde the see were kept for any thynge
Be twixe Middelburghw and orewell
Well cowde he in his eschaungis seye ⁊ selle
This worthy man full well his wit he sette
Ther wiste no wyght that hee was in dette
So esstately was hee of his governawnce
Wtith his bargeynis and wtith his chevissavnce
For sothe hee was a worthy man wtith alle
But sohtlye to seyin I not what mēm hym calle
¶ A Clerk theer was of Oxenforde also
That vnto logik hadde longge igo
As lene was his hors as is a Rake
And hee ne was novt Ryght fat I vndertake
But hee lokede holwe ⁊ therto soberly
Full thredbare was his over courtepy
For hee hadde getyn hym no benefice
No was so worldly to haue noon offyis
For hym was leuere to haue atte his beddis heed
Twenty bokys clad in blac and Reed
Of Aristotele and his phelosofye
Thanne Robis Riche or fythele or gay sawtrie
But all yif that hee were a philosofre
Yit hadde hee but lytell gold in cofere
But all that hee myghtte of his frendis hentte
On bokis and on lernyngge hee it spent
And besily gan for the sowlis pray
For the sowlis that hym to skole foond ay
Of scolie toke hee most cvre and hede
Nowt oo word spac hee more thanne was nede
And that was seyd in forme and Reuerence
In schort termis and heygh of centtence
Sownygge in morall vertew was his speche
And gladly wolde hee lerne ⁊ gladly wolde he teche
¶ A sergeant of lawe waar and wyis
That often hadde been atte ꝑpervies
That was full Riche of exelence
Diskrete hee was and of greet Reverence
Hee semede swich his wordis werēm so vyze
Iustize hee was full often in assyze
By patent and by playn comissioūn
Fore his science ⁊ fore his heygh Renoūn
Of feis and Robis hadde hee manye on
So greet a purchasour was nowher non
All was fee symple to hym in effecte
His prrachasyngge nowght been in fecte
Nowhere so besy a man as hee there nas
And yit hee semede besiere thanne hee was
In termys hadde hee caas ⁊ domis alle
That fro tyme of kyng willīnm weere falle
Therto he cowde endite ⁊ make a thyng
Theer cowthe no wyght pinche at his writyng
And everi stateute cowthe hee playn be Rote
Hee Rood but homly in a medly cote
Gert wtith a seynt of selk wtith barris smale
Of his array tell I no lengere tale
¶ A frankeleyn was in his cvmpanye
Wyght was his berd as is the daysie
Of his compleccioūn hee was sangwyne
Weell louede hee bee the morwe a sop īn wyne
To leuin in delyte evere was his wone
Fore hee was Epiourues owne sone
That held opiniovn that playn delite
That was verray felicite ꝑperfite
An hows haldere and that a greet was hee
Seynt ivlian hee was in his cvntree
His bred his ale was alweys after oone
A bettere envined man was ther nowher noōmne
Wtith owten bake mete was nevere his hows
Of fychs of flechs and that so plentews
Hit snowede in his hows of mete ⁊ of drynke
Of all deyntteis that mēm cowthe on thynke
After the svndry sesownis of thee yeere
So chawngede he his mete and his sopere
Full manye afat ꝑpertrich hadde hee in Mewe
And manye a breme ⁊ manye a luce īn stewe
Woo was his coke but his sawce were
Poynowt and scharp ⁊ redy all his gere
His table dormant in his halle alwey
Stode Redy couered all thee longge day
Atte sescions theer was hee lord and sire
Well ofte tymis hee was knyght of the schire
An anelas and a gepcer all of selk
Hyng atte his gerdil wyght as morne Melk
A schereve hadde hee been and a covmptour
Was nowhere swiche a worthy vauaser
¶ An haberdasschere and a carpenter
A Webbe a dyere and a tapicer
And they were klothed all in oo lyuere
Of a solempne and a greet fraternete
Full frechs and newe here gere a piked was
Here knivis ne were nowt chapid wtith bras
But all wtith seluir wrowght full klene ⁊ weell
Here gerdelis and here powchis everideell
Well somede eche of hem a feyir burgeys
To sitte in a yelde halle on the deyis
Everich for the wyisdom that hee can
Were schaply forto be an alderman
For catell hadde they inowgh and Rentte
And also here wyvis wolde it weell ascentte
And ellis Certeyn they were to blame
Fore it is full feyir to be klepid Madame
And gon to vigelyis all be fore
And to have a mentell Riallye ibore
¶ A kooc they hadde wtith hem for the nonis
To boyle the chikkynnis wtith the Maribonis
And powdre Marchawnt tart and gallynggale
Well cowde hee knowe a drawghtte of good ale
Hee cowde Rooste sethe broyle and frye
Make Mortrewys and weell baken a pye
But greet harm it was as thowghtte mee
That on his schene a Mormale hadde hee
For blank mavnger made hee wtith the beste
¶ A schipman was theere wonyngge feer be weste
Fore owght I woot hee was of dertemowthe
Hee Rood on a Rowncy as hee kowthe
In a gowne of faldyngge vnto thee knee
A daggere hangynge on a laas hadde hee
Abowte his necke vnder his arm a down
Thee hote svnne hadde maade his hewe all brown
And certeinlye hee was a good felawe
Full manye a drawghtte of wyin hadde he drawe
From Burdeuxwardis while thee Chapmen slepe
Of nyce concience took hee no kepe
¶ And yif hee fawght and hadde the heyere honde
Bee water hee sentte hem hom to every londe
But of his craft to Rekene well his tydis
His stremis and his dawnger hym bisydis
His herberwe and his moone and his ledmannage
Theer was noon swich fram hull to Cartage
Hardy hee was ⁊ wyis to vndertake
Wtith manye a temppest hadde his beerd be schake
Hee knewe all the havenis as they were
Froo Goot lond to the Cape defynystere
And every krike in Breteyne and in spaygne
His barge kleped hit was thee Mawdeleyne
¶ Wtith vs ther was a doctour of phisik
In all this world ne was theer nōmn hym ilyik
Forto speke of phesik and of svrgerie
For hee was grownded in astronomye
Hee kepte his pacient a full greet deell
In howres by his magik naturell
Well cowde hee fortune the ascendent
Of his Imagis for his pacient
Hee knew the cawze of every Maledye
Were it of hoot or koold moyist or dreye
¶ And wheer he Engendrede and of what hvmoa
Hee was a verray ꝑperfyit practisowr
Thee Cawse I knowe ⁊ of his harm the Roote
Annon hee gaf the syke man his boote
Full Redy hadde hee his a potecaryis
To sende hym and his letewaries
Fore eche of hem made other forto wynne
Here frendschipe ne was not newe forto begynne
Weell knew hee thee Oolde Escalapius
And descorides and Eeke Rusus
Oolde ypocras Haly and Galien
Serapion Razis and Auyren
Auerois damascien and costantyne
Bernard and Gatisdene and Gilbertine
Offe his diete mesurable was hee
Fore hit was of no suꝑperfluitee
But of greet nurschingge ⁊ digestable
His studie was but litell on the bible
In sangweyn and in peers hee was klad all
Lined wtith taffata and wtith sendall
And yit hee was but esy of desspence
Hee kepte that hee hadde wonne in pestelēmce
For gold in phisik is a cordiall
Theer fore hee louede gold in speciall
¶ A good wyif theer was of be syde bathe
But sche was svmdell deef ⁊ that was skathe
Of klooht makynge she hadde swiche an hawnt
Sche paste hem of ypris and Also gawnt
In all thee ꝑpersche wyif was theere noon
That to thee offryngge to forn here scholde goon
And yif theer dede Certeyin wroht was schee
That schee was owt of all charitee
Here kerchevis full fyne were of grownde
I durste well swere they weyeden ten pownde
That on a soneday weren on here heed
Here hozyn weren of fyn skarlett Reed
Full streyt teyid ⁊ schois full moyste ⁊ newe
Bold was here face feyir and Reed offe hewe
Sche was was a worthy wōmman īn to all here lyve
Howsbondis atte chirche doure sche hadde five
Wtith owten other cvmpanye in here yowthe
But ther offe nedyht nowght to speke nowthe
And thries hadde schee been in Ieruzalem
And sche hadde passed manye a sterne strem
Atte Rome sche hadde been ⁊ atte boloygne
In Galeyis atte seyint iame ⁊ atte coloygne
Sche cowthe moche in wandryngge bee the wey
Gattothed schee was thee sothe forto sey
Vppon an awmblere Eesilye schee satt
Y wymplid weell And on here heed an hatt
As brood as is abokeler ore a targe
A foote mantell a bowte here hepis large
And vppon here feet a peyre sporis scharpe
In good felawschepe well cowthe sche lawghe ⁊ carpe
Of remedyis of loue schee knew ꝑperchawnce
For sche cowthe of that Arte the kolde dawnce
¶ A good man was there but nowght of Religioūn
But a powre ꝑpersoun of a lytell town
Riche hee was of holy thowght and werk
Hee was also A lerned man ⁊ a good clerk
That Ciristis gospell trewly wolde hee preche
And his ꝑperschins devowtly wolde hee teche
Benigne hee was and wonder diligent
And in all aduercite wonder pacient
And swich hee was previd ofte sithis
Full loht were hym to cvrce for his tithis
But Rathere wolde hee yevēm wtith owten dowte
Vnto his poure pareschenis all abowte
Of his offrynge and of his substawnce
Hee covthe in lytell thyng have suffisavnce
Wyid was his ꝑpersche and hosis feer a svnder
But hee ne lefte nowther for Reyin no thvnder
In siknesse nor in Meschef to visite
Thee fertheste in his ꝑpersche bothe moche ⁊ lyte
Vppon his feet and in his hond a staf
This noble ensample to his scheep hee yaf
Ferst hee wrowghtte ⁊ after that hee tawghtte
Owtith of thee gospell hee the wordis Rawghtte
And this figure hee addede eeke theerto
That yif gold Ruste what scha yren doo
For yif a preest bee fow on whom we trvste
No wonder is offe alewyd man yif hee Ruste
And thee it is yif apreest take kepe
A schetyn schiphertte and aklene schepe
Weell owghtte apreest ensavmple forto yeve
By his klennesse how that his scheep scholde leue
Hee sette nowght his benefyis to here
And leet his scheep a cvmbre in the Myre
¶ And Ran to londoūn vnto seyint powlis
To seke hym a chavntrie to syngge for sowlis
Ore wtith a bretherede forto been wtith wtith holde
But dwelte attom and kepte well his foolde
So that thee wolf made hit nowt miscarie
Hee was a schepꝑperde but nowght a mercenarie
And thowgh hee holy were ān vertews
Hee was nowght to synfull men disspitows
No of his speche dawngerus no dygne
But in his techyngge diskrete and benygne
To drawen folk to heuene by feyirnesse
By goode ensamplis this was his besinesse
But hit were any ꝑpersone that were obstenat
What so that hee were of heygh a state
Hem wolde hee snibbe scharplye for the nonis
A bettre preest I trowe that nowher noon is
Hee waytede after no pompe no Revenere
Nowt to make hym a spicid concience
But cristis lore ⁊ his apostelis twelve
He tawghtte but hee folwede it hym selue
¶ Wtith hym theer was a plowman was his brother
Hadde lad dvng on feelld manye a fother
And a good swnkkere and a trewe was hee
Levingge in pees and in ꝑperfite charitee
God louede hee best wtith all his herte
Att all tymis thowght hee gamede or smerte
And thanne his neyghebour Ryght as hym selue
Hee wolde thressche ⁊ therto dike ⁊ delve
For Ciritis sake for every pore wyght
Wtith owten any hyire yif it laye in his myght
His tithis payde hee feyire and weell
Bothe offe his ꝓpropre swynk and of his catell
In a Russet tabard hee Rood vppon a mere
¶ Theere was also a Reeve and a Mellere
A svmpnour and a ꝑperdoner ther was alsoo
A Mavnciple and I my self there were no moo
Thee Mellere was a stowt carle fore the nonis
Full byg hee was of brawn ⁊ eke of bonis
That ꝓprovede well for over all there hee cam
Atte the wrastelyngge hee wolde haue the Ram
Hee was thicke schuldred ⁊ a schort knarre
Theer was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it atte a Rennyngge wtith his heede
His beerd as any sowe or fox was Reede
And therto brood as it were a spade
Vppon thee kop Right of his noze hee hade
A wertte ⁊ theer onne stood a tofte of heris
Reede as thee brestelis of a sowis Eeris
His nose thrillis were blac ⁊ wyde
A swerd wtith a bokeler bare hee be his side
His Mowht was as greet as a greet furneyis
Hee was a gangelere and a goliardeys
And that was most of senne ⁊ of harlottrie
Well cowthe stele corn and tolle thryis
And yit hee hadde a thumbe of gold ꝑperde
A wyght cote and a blew hood werede hee
A bagge pipe well cowthe hee blowe ⁊ sowne
And there wtith all hee browghtte vs owt of towne
¶ A gentell Mavnciple was there of a temple
Of wyche a catoure myghtte taken a sample
Forto beēm wyis in beyinge of vetayle
For wheyther that hee pay or take bee tayle
Also hee awaytede so his a cate
That hee was ay before and in good state
Now is nowght that of god well feyir garace
That swich alewid mannis wit schall pace
Thee wisdom of an heep of lerned men
Of Maystris hadde he mo thanne thries ten
That were of lawe exꝑperte and corious
Of wyche theer was a dozeyn in that hows
Worthy to been stewardis of Rentte ⁊ londe
Offe any lordis that is in Engelonde
To make hym leue by his propre good
In honovr detteles but yif hee were wood
Ore leue als scarsly as hym lyst desire
And able to helpen alle a schire
In any caas that myghtte happe
And yit thee Mavnceple sette here alter cappe
¶ Thee Reve was a skendere colerik man
His beerd was schaue as neygh as hee can
His heere was by his erin full Rownd schorn
His toppe was docked lyik apreest by forn
Full longge were his leggis and lene
Ylike a staf theer was no calf isene
Well cowthe hee kepe a gerner or abynne
Theer was noon awditour that cowde of hym w
Weell woste hee by the drowghtte ⁊ by the Reyne
Thee yeldingge of his seed ⁊ of his greyine
His lordis scheep his neet his dayrie
His swyin his hors his stoor ⁊ his pultrie
Was all hollye in this Revis governyngge
And bee his covenawnt yaf the Rekenyngge
Syn that his lord was xx winter of age
Theer cowthe no man bryngge hym in a Rerage
Theere ne was bayli no heerde no Other hyne
That hee ne knew his sleyghtte ⁊ his covine
They weren a drad of hym as of thee deeht
His wonyngge was full feyre vppon an heeht
Wtith grene treis schadewid was his place
Hee cowde bettere thanne his lord parachace
Full Riche hee was a stored previly
His lord hee cowde well plezen subtilly
To yeve and lene hym offe his owne goode
And haue a thank ⁊ yit a cote and hoode
In yowthe hee hadde lerned a good mystere
He was a well good wrighte a carpentere
This Reve satte vppon a Full good stot
That was all pomely grey and heyhtte skot
A long surkote of peers vppon hee haade
And bee his syde hee baar a rusty blade
Of norhtfolke was this Reve of whiche I tell
By syde a town that men klepyn it Baldeswell
Tuckyd hee was as is afrere a bowte
And evere hee Rood the hyndereste of owre Rowte
¶ A svmnowr was there wtith vs in that place
That hadde a verry cherubinnys face
For savcefleme hee was ⁊ wtith Eeyen narwe
Als hoot hee was and leccherows as asparwe
Wtith scalled browis blac and pelid beerd
Of his vesage chyldren were affereed

(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wtith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaūnt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graūnt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
(base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde
(base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
(base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
(base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
(base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite wook and sterte
(base) Now trewely / how sore that me smerte
(base) Quod he / to Atthenes right now wol I fare
(base) Ne for the drede of deeth / shal I nat spare
(base) To se my lady / that I loue and serue
(base) In hir presence / I recche nat to sterue
(base) ¶ And with that word / he caughte a greet Mirour
(base) And saugh / that chaunged was al his colour
(base) And saugh his visage / al in another kynde
(base) And right anoon / it ran hym in his mynde
(base) That sith his face / was so disfigured
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of maladie / the which he hadde endured
(base) He myghte wel / if that he bar hym lowe
(base) Lyue in Atthenes / eueremoore vnknowe
(base) And seen his lady / wel ny / day by day
(base) And right anoon / he chaunged his array
(base) And cladde hym / as a poure laborer
(base) And al allone / saue oonly a Squyer
(base) That knew his pryuetee / and al his cas
(base) Which was disgised / pourely as he was
(base) To Atthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
(base) And to the Court he wente vpon a day
(base) And at the gate / he profreth his seruyse
(base) To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuyse
(base) ¶ And shortly / of this matere / for to seyn
(base) He fil in office / with a Chambreleyn
(base) The which / that dwellyng was wtith Emelye
(base) For he was wys / and koude soone espye
(base) Of euery seruant which that serueth here
(base) Wel koude he / hewen wode / and water bere
(base) For he was yong . and myghty for the nones
(base) And ther to / he was strong and byg of bones
(base) To doon / what any wight kan hym deuyse
(base) A yeer / or two / he was in this seruyse
(base) Page of the chambre / of Emelie the brighte
(base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte
(base) ¶ But half so wel biloued a man / as he
(base) Ne was ther neuere in Court of his degree
(base) He was so gentil / of condicioun
(base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
(base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
(base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
(base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse
(base) But Palamon / that loue destreyneth so
(base) That wood out of his wit he gooth for wo
(base) And eek ther to / he is a prisoner
(base) Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yer
(base) Who koude ryme / in englissh proprely
(base) His martirdom / for sothe it am noght I
(base) Therfore I passe / as lightly / as I may
(base) ¶ It fil / that / in that seuenthe yeer of May
(base) I wylle not taire yow alle the day
(base) The thridde nyght . as olde bokes seyn
(base) That al this storie / tellen moore pleyn
(base) Were it by auenture / or destynee
(base) As whan a thyng is shapen / it shal be
(base) That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun
(base) By helpyng of a freend / brak his prisoun
(base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go
(base) For he hadde yeue / his Gailler drynke so
(base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn
(base) With Nercotikes / and opye / of Thebes fyn / /
(base) That al that nyght . thogh that men wolde hym shake
(base) The Gailler sleep / he myghte noght awake
(base) ¶ And thus he fleeth / as faste as euere he may
(base) The nyght was short and faste by the day
(base) That nedes cost he moste hymseluen hyde
(base) And til a groue / faste ther bisyde
(base) With dreedful foot thanne stalketh Palamoun
(base) For shortly / this was his opynyoun
(base) That in that groue / he wolde hym hyde al day
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And in the nyght thanne wolde he take his way
(base) To Thebesward / his freendes for to preye
(base) On Theseus / to helpe hym to werreye
(base) And shortly / outher he wolde lese his lyf /
(base) Or wynnen Emelie / vnto his wyf
(base) This is the effect and his entente pleyn
(base) ¶ Now wol I turne / to Arcite ageyn
(base) That litel wiste / how neigh that was his care
(base) Til that Fortune / hadde broght hym / in the snare
(base) ¶ The bisy larke / messager of day
(base) Salueth in hir song the morwe gray
(base) And firy Phebus / riseth vp so brighte
(base) That al the Orient . laugheth of the lighte
(base) And with his stremes / dryeth in the greues
(base) The siluer dropes / hangynge on the leues
(base) And Arcita / that in the Court roial
(base) With Theseus / is Squyer principal
(base) Is risen / and looketh on the murye day
(base) And for to doon / his obseruance to May
(base) Remembrynge / on the point of his desir
(base) He on a Courser / startlynge as the fir
(base) Is riden in to the feldes / hym to pleye
(base) Out of the Court . were it a myle / or tweye
(base) And to the groue / of which that I yow tolde
(base) By auenture / his wey he gan to holde
(base) To maken hym / a gerland of the greues
(base) Were it of wodebynde / or hawethorn leues
(base) And loude he soong . ayein the sonne shene
(base) May / with alle thy floures / and thy grene
(base) Wel come be thow / faire fresshe May
(base) In hope / that I som grene gete may
(base) And from his courser / with a lusty herte
(base) In to the groue / ful hastily he sterte
(base) And in a path / he rometh vp and doun
(base) Ther as by auenture / this Palamoun
(base) Was in a bussh / that no man myghte hym se
(base) For soore afered / of his deeth was he
(base) No thyng knew he / that it was Arcite
(base) God woot he wolde haue trowed it ful lite
(base) But sooth is seyd / go sithen many yeris
(base) That feeld hath eyen / and the wode hath erys
(base) It is ful fair / a man to bere hym euene
(base) For alday meeten men / at vnset steuene
(base) Ful litel woot Arcite / of his felawe
(base) That was so neigh / to herknen al his sawe
(base) For in the bussh / he sitteth now ful stille
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / hadde romed al his fille
(base) And songen al the roundel lustily
(base) In to a studie / he fil sodeynly
(base) As doon thise louerys / in hir queynte gerys
(base) Now in the crop / now down in the brerys
(base) Now vp / now down / as boket in a welle
(base) Right as the friday / soothly for to telle
(base) Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
(base) Right so / kan gery Venus ouercaste
(base) The hertes of hir folk . right as hir day
(base) Is gerful / right so chaungeth she array
(base) Selde is the friday / al the wike ylike
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite hadde songe / he gan to syke
(base) And sette hym down / withouten any moore
(base) Allas quod he / that day / that I was bore
(base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde
(base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
(base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wtith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe
(base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
(base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
(base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
(base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.
(base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe
(base) Or he moot sle me / if that me myshappe
(base) So ferden they / in chaungyng of hir hewe
(base) As fer / as euerich / oother of hem knewe
(base) ¶ Ther nas no good day / ne no saluynge
(base) But streight withouten word / or rehersynge
(base) Euerich of hem / heelp for to armen oother
(base) As frendly / as he weere / his owene brother
(base) And after that with sharpe speres stronge
(base) They foynen / ech at oother / wonder longe
(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun
(base) In his fightyng were a wood leoun
(base) And as a crewel Tygre / was Arcite
(base) As wilde boores / gonnen they to smyte
(base) That frothen / whit as foom / for Ire wood
(base) Vp to the Anclees / foghte they in hir blood
(base) And in this wise / I lete hem fightyng dwelle
(base) And forth I wole / of Theseus yow telle
(base) ¶ The destynee / Ministre general
(base) That executeth / in the world oueral
(base) The purueiance / that god hath seyn biforn
(base) So stroong it is / that thogh the world hadde sworn
(base) The contrarie of a thyng by ye / or nay
(base) Yet som tyme / it shal fallen on a day
(base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer
(base) For certeinly / oure appetites heer
(base) Be it of werre / or pees / or hate / or loue
(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May
(base) That in his bed / ther daweth hym no day
(base) That he nys clad / and redy for to ryde
(base) With hunte and horn / and houndes hym bisyde
(base) For in his huntyng hath he swich delit
(base) That it is / al his ioye and appetit
(base) To been hymself the grete hertes bane
(base) For after Mars / he serueth now Diane
(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this
(base) And Theseus / with alle ioye and blys
(base) With his ypolita / the faire queene
(base) And Emelie / clothed al in greene
(base) On huntyng be they riden roially
(base) And to the groue / that stood ful faste by
(base) In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
(base) Duc Theseus / the streighte wey hath holde
(base) And to the launde / he rideth hym ful right
(base) For thider was the hert wont haue his flight
(base) And ouer a brook / and so forth on his weye
(base) This duc / wol han a cours at hym / or tweye

(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt

div.l: (base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle
(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
(base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde
(base) But o cours / with a sharp ygrounde spere
(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
