And all this schee schall doo in thy presence
I wole nowght speke owt of thyin audience
¶ And in that chawmber while they were abowte
Here tretyse wiche yee schull her after heere
Thee peple com into thee hows wtith owte
And wondrede hem in how honest manere
And how tentyfully schee kepte hiere fader dere
But vutterly Grisilde wondur myghtte
For neuere erft ne sawe schee swich a syghtte
¶ Noo wonder ne is thowgh schee bee astoned
To see soo greet a gestenyngge come into that place
Sche was neuer to swiche gestis woned
For wychee schee lokede wtith full pale face
But schortlye fro this mater forto pace
This were thee wordis that this Marquis seyde
To this benyngne verray fayhtfull mayde
¶ Grisilde hee seyde yee wole well vnderstonde
Hit lykiht vnto yowre fader and mee
That I yow wedde ⁊ eke it may soo stonde
As I suppose that yee wole that it so bee
But this demaunde I aske ferst qd hee
That schithen it schall bee doon in hasty wyse
Wole yee assentte or ellis yow avise
¶ I seye thus bee yee redy wtith good hertte
To alle my lustis and that I frely may
As mee best thynkyht do yow lawghe or smertte
And yee neuere grucche nowther nyght no day
And eke whanne I seye yee seye ye nowt nay
Nowther by word no by froward cuntinawce
Swere this and heere I sere owre alyaunce
¶ Wondryngge vppon this word quakynge for drede
Shee seyde Indigne and vn worthy
Am I to that as as that yee mee bede
But ryght as yee wole yowre self soo wole I
And I swere that neuere willingly
In word in thowght I neuere will yow disobeye
Forto bee deed ⁊ yit were mee looht to deye
¶ This is Inowgh Grisilde myin quod hee
And foorht hee gooht wtith a sobre chere
Owt atte thee dore and after com schee
And vnto thee peple hee seyde on this manere
This is my wyif qd hee that standyht here
Honowrht hiere ⁊ loueht hiere I yow praye
Whoo soo louyht mee ther is nomore to seiy
¶ And fore no thyng of hiere oolde gere
Schee schulde bryngge to his hows hee bad
that women shulde speyle hiere ryght there
O wiche thes ladyis were nowght ryght glad
To handle the clothis in the wiche schee was clad
But natheles this mayde bryght of hewe
Fro foot to hond clothed was sche newe
Here heris han they kembed that lay vntressed
Well fetislye wtith hiere fyngris smalie
And a crowne on hiere heed they hauen dressed
And sette it full of owchis greet and smale
O hiere array what scholde I make a tale
Vnnethe thee peple hiere knewe fore hiere fayrnesse
Whanne shee transformed was in swich richesse
¶ This Marquis hath hiere spoused wtith a ryng
Bowght fore thee same cause and thanne hire sette
Vppon an hors snow white ⁊ well amblynge
And to his paleys er hee lengere lette
With Ioyfull peple that hee ladde and mette
Conueyede hiere and thus thee day they spende
In reuelle tille thee sunne gan to dessende
¶ And schortlye foorht this tale forto chace
I seye that to this newe Marquissesse
God hath sent swich fauour of his grace
That it semed nowght as by lyiknesse
That schee was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in a oxe stalle
But as schee were nurschid in an Emꝑperouris halle
¶ To euery wyght sche woxen is soo dere
And worschipfull that folke there as sche was bore
And froo hiere berthe knewe hiere fro yeer to yerre
Vnnethe trowede they but durste haue swore
That to Ianicula of whiche I spake byfore
Sche dowghtter ne were fore as by coniecutre
Hem thowghtte schee was another creature
¶ For that euere vertewous was schee
Schee was enkresed in swiche excellence
Of condessionys sette in heyghe bounte
And so diskrete and feyir of eloquence
Soo benigne and digne of reuerence
And cowde thee peplis herttis so enbrace
That euerich hiere louede that lokede in hiere face
¶ Nowght onlye of saluce in thee town
Publisschid was thee bownte of hiere name
And Eeke bee syde in manye a regioun
Yif oon seyde weell an nother seyde the same
Soo spradde of hiere bownte thee famed
That men and women bothe yonge ⁊ oolde
Goone to Saluce hiere to bee hoolde
¶This Watere lowlye nay but rially
Weddyht wiht fortewne honeste
In goddis pees lyueht well esily
Attome and owt wardis garace Inowgh hadd hee
And for hee sawe vnder lowe degree
Was often vertew hyd thee peple hym heelde
A prudent man and that is seen full seelde
¶ Nowght oonlye Grisilde thus thurghw hiere wit
Cowde all thee feete of wyifly homblynsse
But eke whanne thee caas required it
thee comune profyit cowde schee redresse
Theer nas diskord rancour no heuinesse
In alle thee lond that schee ne cowthe it cese
And brynge hem al wyislye in reste and ese
¶ Though that hiere housbande pꝰersent were or noon
Yif genttell men or othere of hiere cuntre
Were wrooht schee wode bryng hem atton
So wyse and ripe wordis hadde sche
And Iugement of so greet equite
That schee froo heuene was come as mēm wende
Thee peple to saue ⁊ euery wrong to amende
¶ Nowght long tyme after that this Grisilde
Was wedded schee a dowghtter hath bore
Alle had schee leuere haue borne a knaue chyilde
Glad was thee Marquis and his folk theerfore
For thowgh a mayden chyild come alle by fore
Shee may after to a knaue chyilde atteyine
By liklye heede sythenys schee is nowt barayne
¶ Theer fore as it fallyht tymes moo
Whanne this chyild hath soken but a throwe
This Marquis in his hertte longgyht soo
To tempte his wyif hiere sadnesse to knowe
that hee ne myghtte froo his herte throwe
This marueylus desire his wyif to assaye
Natheles god woot hee thowghtte hiere to affraye
¶ Hee hadde assaye hiere Inowgh bee fore
And foonde hiere euere good what nedyht hit
Hiere forto trmentte and alwey more and more
Thowgh men preyse it fore a sotell witte
But as for mee I seye that euele it sitte
To assaye a wyif whanne it is no nede
And to putte hiere in awngys and in drede
¶ For whiche this Marquis wrowghtte on this manere
Hee come a nyght allone theer as schee lay
Wtith sterne face and trowble chere
And seyde thes Grisilde quod hee that day
That I yow toke owt of yowre poure aray
And putte yow in esstate hey noblesse
Yee haue nowt yit for geten as I gesse
¶ I seye Grisilde this present dignyte
In wiche I haue putte yow as I trowe
Makyht nowt yow for yetfull forto bee
That I yow toke in pouere estate full lowe
For any thyng yee mote yowre seluen knowe
Take heede of euery word that I yow say
Theere is noon that heeryht this but wee tweye
¶ Yee woot yowre self how that yee come heere
In to this hows it is nowght longe a goo
And thowgh to mee yee bee leef and dere
Vnto my gentelis yee beene nothyng soo
They seyen to hem it is greet schame ⁊ woo
For to bee sogette and in seruage
To thee that art boorne of soo lowe lynage
¶ An namelye sythen thy dowghter was bore
Thise wordis hauen they spoken dowtelees
But I desire as I haue done by fore
Too lyue my lyif / wtith hem in reste and pees
I ne may nowght in this caas been recheles
I moste doon wtith thy dowghtter for thee beste
Nowght as I wolde but as my gentelis leste
¶ And yit god woot this is full looht to mee
But natheles wtith owten yowre wytingge
I wole nowt doo but this I wole qd hee
That yee to mee assentte as in this thyngge
Shewtith pure pacience now in yowre worchyng
That yee mee by heyghtte ⁊ swore īn yowre vilage
That day that makyd was owre marige
¶ Whanne shee hadde herd al this sche was ⁊absent:nowtnowtmeued
Neyther in word nor chere nowther in cuntenaūnce
For as it semede schee was nowght greued
Schee seyde lord ll lyght in yowre plesaunce
My chyild and I wtith hertily obeysaunce
Wee been yowris all ⁊ yee mayue saue ⁊ spill
Yowre owne thyng to beene atte yowre will
¶ Ther may no thyng so god my sowle saue
Lyknge to yow that may displese mee
Noo I dessyre noo thyng atte al to haue
Noo drede to leese saue oonlye yee
This is myin hertte will and ay schall bee
Noo lengthe of tyme till deeht it may deface
Noo chaungge myn corarage in to other place
¶ Glad was thee Marykys for hiere anssweringe
But yit hee feynede as hee were nowt soo
All drery was his chere and his lokynge
Whenne hee schulde owt of thee chaumber goo
Sone after that aforlong wey or twoo
Hee playnlye hath toolde his ententte
Vnto a man withe hee to his wyif sentte
A maner seriawnt was this preuy man
The wiche that feyhtfull fownde hee hadde
In thynges greet ⁊ eke swiche folkis well can
Soo execucioun offe thyngis badde
Thee lord knewe weell hee hym louede ⁊ dradde
And ehane the seriant wiste his lordis will
In to thee chaumber hee stalkede full still
¶ Madame hee seyde yee moste for geue it mee
Thowgh I do thyng to wiche I am consstreyned
Yee been so wyis that ryght well knowe ye
That lordis heestis may nowt been feyned
They may weell bee wayled and conpleyned
But men mote nede vnto here lustis obeye
And soo wole I theer is no more to seye
¶ That chyild I am comaunded to take
And spak no more but owt thee chyild hee hentte
Dispitouslye and gan a chere to make
As hee wellehauen slayen hit ore hee wentte
Grisilde moot all suffre and all concentte
And as a lombe schee sittyht meke ⁊ stille
And leet this crewell seriaunt haue his wille
¶ Suspecte was thee fame of this man
Suspecte his face suspecte his words also
Suspecte thee tyme that hee this began
For his dowghtter that schee louede soo
Schee wende hee wolde haue slayn it ryght thoo
But natheles schee neyther weptte ne schiikede
Conformyngge hiere to that the Marques likede
¶ And ⁊absent:atatthee laste speke schee by gan
And mekly to thee seriaunt prayde
Soo as hee was a worthy genttell man
That schee moste kysse hiere chyild ere hit deyde
And in hiere barme this lytell chyild schee leyde
Wtith full sad face ⁊ gan thee chyilde to blesse
And lullede hit and after gan it to kesse
¶ And thus schee seyde in hiere benygne voyis
Fare well my chyild I schal thee neuere see
But syhtths I haue marked thee wtith thee croyis
Of thilke fader blessed moste thow bee
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy sowle lytell chyild I hym bee take
For this nyght schalt thow deye for my sake
¶ I trowe that to a norise in this caas
Hit hadd been hard this rewthe forto see
Weell moste a Moder thanne crien allas
But natheles so sadde and stedefast was hee
That sche endurede all hiere aduercitee
And to thee seriaunt meelye schee seyde
Haue mercy on my yonge lytell mayde
And gooht now quod schee now ⁊ doo my lordis heste
And oo thyng weolde I praye yow of yowre garace
But yif my lord forbede it yow atte thee leeste
Beryeht this lytell body in sume place
That noo beestys no briddis hit to race
But hee no word to thee purpos wolde seye
But toke thee chyild and wentte foorht his weye
¶ This seriaunt come vnto thee lorde a gayne
And offe Grisilis wordis and of hiere chere
he tolde hym poynit fore poynt in schort ⁊ playn
And hym presentede wtith his dowghtter dere
Sumwhat this lord hadde rewthe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos heeld hee stille
As lordis doon whanne they wole haue here will
¶ And hee bad this seriaunt full preuily
Hee scholde wel softlye this chyild to wyinde ⁊ wrappe
Whit all thee circumstawnce tenderly
And carie hit in a cofere ore in a lappe
But vppon peyne his heed offe to swappe
That noo man scholde knowe of his entente
Nee whens hee come no wheder hee wente
¶ But to Baloyne to his owne suster dere
That thoo of piuye was countesee
He scholde hit take ⁊ schewe hiere this matere
By sechyngge hiere to doon hiere besynesce
This chyild to fostre in alle gladnesee
And whos chyild it was hee bad bad hiere hyde
Fram euery wyght for owt that myghtte betyde
¶ This seriaunt wentte to fulfelle this thyng
But to theis Marquis now returne wee
For now gooht hee well ofte ymagenyng
Yif by his wyif that hee myghtte see
And by hiere wordis parceyue that schee
Were chawnged but hee cowde it neuere fyinde
But euere in oon I lyke sad and kyinde
¶ As glad as humble as besy in all seruise
And eke in loue as schee was wont to bee
Was schee to hym in euery maner wyse
Nee of hiere dowghtter a word spke schee
None accident for noon aduercitee
Was seen in hiere ne neuere hir dowghtter name
Nempnede schee for ernest ne for gamee
¶ In this estate passed been fowre yeere
Ere schee wtith chyilde was but as god wolde
A knaue chyilde chee baar by this Watere
Well gracious And feyir to behoolde
And whanne foolk it to hiere fader toolde
Nowght oonlye hee but all thee cuntre merye
Weren for thee chyilde ⁊ god they thanke ⁊ herie
¶ Whanne it was two yeer oolde ⁊ fram the brest
Departed from his norise vppon a day
his marquis cawghtte yit another liest
To tempten his wyif oftere yif hee may
Oo needles was schee tempted in assay
But wedded men knowen no mesure
Whanne they fyinde a pacient creature
¶ Wyif quod this marquis yee haue herd or this
My peple speke heuilye of owre mariage
And namelye syhtthen my sone boorn is
Now it is wers thanne euere in owre age
Thee murmure sleyht myn herte ⁊ my corage
For to myne Eeris comyht thee voyis so smerte
That well neygh hit desstroyht myin hertte
¶ Now seyn men thus whanne Walter is a goon
Thanne schall thee blood of Ianycula succede
And been owre lord for other haue wee noon
Swiche wordis seyn my peple it is no drede
Well awghtte I of swich murmr take hede
For certeynlye I drede swiche sentence
Thowgh they nowt pleynly speke īn myn audience
¶ I wolde lyue in pees yif that I myghtte
Wherfore I am desposid witterly
As I his suster seruede by nyghtte
Ryght soo I thenke to serue hym preuily
This warne I yow that yee nowt sodeynly
Owt of yowre self for no woo schulde owtraye
Beeht pacient and theer offe I yow praye
¶ I haue seyd quod schee and euere seye schall
That I will of no thyng dessyre certayn
But as yow lust nowght greuiht mee at all
Thowgh my dowghtter ⁊ my sone bee slayn
Atte yowre comoundement that is to sayn
I haue had now part of children tweyne
Ferst but syiknesse and after woo ⁊ peyne
¶ Yee been owre lord doo wtith yowere owne thyng
Ryght as yow lust and askeht no reed of mee
For as I lefte att hom all my klothynge
Whanne I com ferst to yow ryght so quod schee
Lefte I my will and all my libertee
And toke yowre klothynge wheer fore I yow praye
Doo yowre wil I wille to hit obeye
¶ And certis yif I hadde euy prescience
Yowre wil to knowe or yee yowre lust mee toolde
I wolde it doon wtith owten any neclygence
But now I woot yowre lust and what yee wolde
All yowre plesaunce ferme and stable I hoolde
For wiste I that my deeht wolde doo yow eese
Gladlye wolde I suffre hit yow forto plese
¶ Deeht may make no comparisoun
Vnto yowre loue and whanne this Marquis say
Thee constance of his wyif hee caste his heed a down
And his eeyen two and wondrede how sche may
In swich penaunce suffre al this array
And foorht hee gooht wtith drery cuntenawnce
But to his hertte it was greet plesaunce
¶ This egre seriaunt in thee same wyse
that hee hiere dowghtter cawghtte ryght so hee
Or wersse yif hee cowde wersse deuise
Hath caught hiere chyild that was full of bewtee
And euere in oon so pacient was schee
That schee no chere made of heuynesse
But kepte hiere sone and after gan hym blesse
¶ Saue this schee prayde hym yif that hee myghtte
Hiere lytell sone hee wolde in erthe garaue
His tendre lymes deligate to syghtte
For fowlis and froo besstis hym to saue
But schee noōm ansswerd of hy myght haue
He wentte his way as hee nothyng rowghtte
But into Boloyne tendrlye hit browghtte
¶ This marquis wondreht euer lengere the more
Vppon hiere pacience and yif that hee
Nee hadde hee soohtlye knowen bee fore
That parfyitlye hiere children louede schee
hee wolde haue wend that of sum soteltee
And of maleys ore of crewell corage
That schee hadde suffred this wtith sad visage
¶ But hee knew that next hym self certayn
Schee loued hiere children best on euery wise
But now of wōmmen wolde I aske fayne
Yif thise assayis myghtte nowght suffyse
What cowde a sturdy hosebonde devise
To proue hiere wyifhood and hiere stedefastnesse
And to bee contynuingge in sturdynesse
¶ But theer bee folk of swich condicioun
That whanne they haue a certeyn purpos take
they can nowt stintte of here entencioun
But as they were bownded vnto a stake
They wold nowght of that purpoos slake
Ryght so this Marquis hath fully purposed
To tempte his wyif as hee was ferst disposed
¶ He waytiht yif by word or cuntinawnce
Yif schee to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere cowde hee fynde variaunce
Schee was euere in hertte and in visage
And euere thee ferthere that schee was in age
Thee more trewer yif it were possible
Schee was to hym in loue and more penyble
¶ For wiche it semyht thus that of hem twoo
Theer was but one will for as Walter lyiste
Thee same lust was hiere plesaunsce also
And god ⁊absent:bebethankyd alle feell for thee beste
Schee schewed weell for no worldly reste
A wyif as offe hiere self no thyng scholde
Willen in effecte but as hiere housebande wolde
¶ The sklaundre of Walter ofte wyde spradde
That offe a crewell herte wickedly
For hee a pore wōmman weddede hadde
And hath murthered bothe his children pdvily
Swich murmur was amongis hem comeunly
No wonder no was for to thee peplis eere
Ther com no word but that they murthered were
¶ For swich as of his peple theer by fore
Hadde loued hym weell disclaundre of his name
Made hem that they hated hym ther fore
To been a murderede is an hatteful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
Hee fore his crewelte wolde nowt stinte
To tempte his wyif was all his entente
¶ Whanne his dowghtter xij yeer was of age
Hee to thee court fo Rome in sotel wyse
Enfourmed of his will sentte his message
Comowndyngge hem swiche billis to devise
As to his crewell purpos may suffise
How that thee pope fore his peplis reste
Bad hym wedde where as hym leste
¶ I seye hee bad they schulde counterfete
Thee papis bullis makyngge mencioun
That hath leue his ferste wyif to lete
As bee thee popis wone dispensacioun
To styntte rancour and dessencioun
By twixe his peple ⁊ hym thus spak the bulle
Thee wiche they haue publisschid atte thee fulle
¶ Thee rude peple as no wonder ne is
Wende full weell is hadde ben ryght soo
But thise tidynggis to Grisilde comen is
I deme ⁊absent:thatthathiere hertte was full woo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey
Incipit pars quinta
Among al this after his wikke vsage
Incipit pars qanta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
GRisilde is deede and eke hiere pacience
And bothe attonis I beried in Itayle
For wiche I crie in open avdience
No wedded man bee hardy for to assayle
His wyvis pacience in trust to fynde
Grisilde fore in certeyn hee schal fayle
¶ Oo noble wyvis ful of heygh prudence
Late noon humilite yowre tungis nayle
No lete no clerk haue cause or diligence
To write of yow a storie of swich Marvele
As offe Grisildes pacience and kynde
Lest chichyuache yow swelwe in hiere entayle
¶ Folwyht ekko that holdyht noo silence
But evere anssweriht atte thes contertayle
Beeht nowt by daffed for yowre Innocence
But scharply take on yow thee governayle
Emprentyht weel this sesovn in yowre mynde
For comvn profytt syhtthe it may avayle
¶ Ne drede hym nowght dooht hem no Reverence
For thowgh thyin housebonde arrayed bee in mayle
Thee arwis of thyin crabbed eloquence
Schal ꝑperce his brest and eeke his adventayle
In Ielousye I Rede eke thow hym byinde
And that thow make hym cowche as dooht a quayle
¶ Yif thow bee fayir theer folk been in precence
Schewe thow thy visage and thyin apparayle
Yif thow bee fowl bee free of thy desspence
To gete thee freendis ay doo thy travayle
Bee ay of chere as lyght as leef on lynde
And late hym care and wepe and wayle
¶ Yee archer wyvis stondyht atte yowre deffence
Syhtthe yee been stronge as is a greet camayle
Ne svffryht nowght that man doo yow offence
And sklendre wyvis feble as in batayle
Beeht Egre as a tygre yonder in yinde
Ay klappyngge as is a Melle I yow cvnseyle
¶ Here endyht the clerk of Oxenforde
¶ Here be gynnyht the ꝓprologe of the frankelyn
I have awyif thowgh sche pore bee
Yit hath sche an heepe of vicis loo
For of hiere tvnge A schreewe is schee
Fore to my will thee cōmtrarie wole sche doo
Theer offe no foors te all swiche thyngis goo
But wite yee what in cvnseyill bee it seyd
Mee Rewyht sore that I am to hiere teyd
¶ Sire Frankeleyn comyht neere yif it yowre will bee
And seye vs atale as yee are agentell man
Hit schall bee doon trewly Ooste quod hee
I wole yow telle as hertilye as I can
Holde mee excused thowgh I vn worthy am
Too tell yow a taale fore I wole nowght rebelle
A yenst yowre will atale now wole I telle

app.rdg:
Haue me ¶ Explicit ꝓprologe excusede if þtat I speke a mys
My will is good and lo my tale is this

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the Frankeleyns tale
(base) Thise olde gentil Britons in hir dayes
(base) Of diuerse auentures maden layes
(base) Rymeyed in hir firste Briton tonge
(base) Whiche layes with hir Instrumentz they songe
(base) Or ellis redden hem for hire plesaunce
(base) And oon of hem haue I in remembraunce
(base) Which I shal seyn with good wyl as I kan
(base) But sires by cause I am a burel man
(base) At my bigynnyng first I yow biseche
(base) Haue me excused of my rude speche
(base) I lerned neuere Rethorik certeyn
(base) Thyng that I speke It moot be bare and pleyn
(base) I sleep neuere in the Mount of parnaso
(base) Ne lerned Marcus Tullius Scithero
(base) Colours ne knowe I none withouten drede
(base) But swiche colours as growen in the mede
(base) Or ellis swiche as men dye or peynte
(base) Colours of Rethoryk they ben to queynte
(base) My Spirit feeleth nat of swich matere
(base) But if yow list my tale shul ye heere
(base) Ther was a knyght that louede and dide his payne
(base) In Armorik that called is Britayne
(base) To serue a lady in his beste wise
(base) And many a labour many a gret emprise
(base) He for his lady wroghte er she were wonne
(base) For she was oon the faireste vnder Sonne
(base) And eek ther to come of so heigh kynrede
(base) That wel vnnethes dorste this knyght for drede
(base) Telle hire his wo his peyne and his distresse
(base) But atte laste she for his worthynesse
(base) And namely for his meke obeysance
(base) Hath swich a pitee caught of his penance
(base) That priuely she fel of his acord
(base) To taken hym for hir housbonde and hir lord
(base) Of swich lordshipe as men han ouer hir wyues
(base) And for to lede the moore in blisse hir lyues
(base) Of his fre wyl he swoor hire as a knyght
(base) That neuere in al his lyf he day ne nyght
(base) Ne sholde vpon hym take no maistrye
(base) Agayn hir wyl ne kithe hire Ialousye
(base) But hire obeye and folwe hir wyl in al
(base) As any louere to his lady shal
(base) Saue that the name of soueraynetee
(base) That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
(base) She thonked hym and with ful gret humblesse
(base) She seyde sire sith of youre gentilesse
(base) Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne

div.l: (base) Ne wolde neuere god bitwix vs tweyne
(base) As in my gilt were outher werre or stryf
(base) Sire I wol be youre humble trewe wyf
(base) Haue heer my trouthe til that myn herte breste
(base) Thus been they bothe in quiete and in reste
(base) For o thyng sires saufly dar I seye
(base) That freendes euerich oother moote obeye
(base) If they wol longe holden compaignye
(base) Loue wol nat be constreyned by maistrye
(base) Whan maistrie comth the god of loue anon
(base) Beteth his wynges and farwel he is gon
(base) Loue is a thyng as any spirit free
(base) Wommen of kynde desiren libertee
(base) And nat to been constreyned as a thral
(base) And so doon men if I sooth seyn shal
(base) Looke who that moost is pacient in loue
(base) He is at his auantage al aboue
(base) Pacience is an heigh vertu certeyn
(base) For it venquysseth as thise clerkes seyn
(base) Thynges that rigour sholde neuere atteyne
(base) For euery word men may nat chide or pleyne
(base) Lerneth to suffre or ellis so moot I gon
(base) Ye shul it lerne wher so ye wole or non
(base) For in this world certeyn ther no wight is
(base) That he ne dooth or seith som tyme amys
(base) Ire siknesse or constellacioun
(base) Wyn wo or chaungyng of complexioun
(base) Causeth ful ofte to doon amys or speken
(base) On euery wrong a man may nat be wreken
(base) After the tyme moste be temperaunce
(base) To euery wight that kan on gouernaunce
(base) And therfore hath this wise worthy knyght
(base) To lyue in ese suffraunce hire bihight
(base) And she to hym ful wisly gan to swere
(base) That neuere sholde ther be defaute in here
(base) Here may men seen an humble wys acord
(base) Thus hath she take hir seruant and hir lord
(base) Seruant in loue and lord in mariage
(base) Thanne was he bothe in lordshipe and seruage
(base) Seruage nay but in lordshipe aboue
(base) Sith he hath bothe his lady and his loue
(base) His lady certes and his wyf also
(base) The which that lawe of loue acordeth to
(base) And whan he was in this prosperitee
(base) Hom with his wyf he gooth to his contree
(base) Nat fer fro Pedmark ther his dwellyng was
(base) Wher as he lyueth in blisse and in solas
(base) Who koude telle but he hadde wedded be
(base) The ioye the ese and the prosperitee
(base) That is bitwix an housbonde and his wyf
(base) A yeer and moore lasted this blisful lyf
(base) Til that the knyght of which I speke of thus
(base) That of kairrud was clepid Arueragus
(base) Shoop hym to goon and dwelle a yeer or twayne
(base) In Engelond that clepid was ek Britayne
(base) To seke in armes worship and honour
(base) For al his lust he sette in swich labour
(base) And dwelled ther two yeer the book seith thus
(base) Now wol I stynte of this Arueragus
(base) And speke I wole of Dorigene his wyf
(base) For his absence wepeth she and siketh
(base) As doon thise noble wyues whan hem liketh
(base) She moorneth waketh waileth fasteth pleyneth
(base) Desir of his presence hir so destreyneth
(base) That al this wide world she set at noght
(base) Hir freendes whiche that knowe hir heuy thoght
(base) Conforten hire in al that euer they may
(base) They prechen hire they telle hire nyght and day
(base) That causelees she sleeth hirself allas
(base) And euery confort possible in this cas
(base) They doon to hire withal hir bisynesse
(base) Al for to make hire leue hir heuynesse
(base) By proces as ye knowen euerichoon
(base) Men may so longe grauen in a stoon
(base) Til som figure ther Inne emprented be
(base) So longe han they conforted hire til she
(base) Receyued hath by hope and by resoun
(base) The emprentyng of hir consolacioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thurgh which hir grete sorwe gan aswage
(base) She may nat alwey duren in swich rage
(base) And eek Arueragus in al this care
(base) Hath sent hire lettres hom of his welfare
(base) And that he wole come hastily agayn
(base) Or ellis hadde this sorwe hir herte slayn
(base) Hire freendes sawe hir sorwe gan to slake
(base) And preyde hire on knees for goddes sake
(base) To come and romen hire in compaignye
(base) Awey to dryue hir derke fantasye
(base) And finally she graunted that requeste
(base) For wel she saw that it was for the beste
(base) Now stood hir Castel faste by the See
(base) And often with hir freendes walketh she
(base) Hir to disporte vpon the bank an heigh
(base) Wher as she many a Ship and Barge seigh
(base) Seillynge hir cours wher as hem liste go
(base) But thanne was that a parcel of hir wo
(base) For of hirself ful ofte allas seith she
(base) Is ther no ship of so manye as I se

div.l: (base) ¶ Why quod this yeman ; / wherto axe ye me ;

Thanne thow woldest goon a paas but a Mile
This poysoun that is soo hard and vyolentte
This cursed man hath it in his hondis hentte
This poysoun in a box and sythenis hee ran
In to thee nexte strete to annother man
And borwede hym large bottellis three
Too his felawis a yen repeyred hee
Thee thridde hee keptte klene for his drynke
For alle that nyght hee schope hym forto swinke
In caryinggere of that gold owt of that place
And whanne this hasardour wtith sory garace
Hadde felled wtith hym his greete botellis three
Too his felawys a yeyn Repeyriht hee
What nedyht it to sermone theer offe more
For Ryght as they hadde cast his deeht by fore
Ryght soo they have hym slayn ⁊ that a noon
Whann that was doon thanne spak that oon
Now lete vs drinke and make vs merye
And afterward wee wole his body berye
And after that it happede hem by caas
Too takyn thee botelle theer inne thee poysoun was
Hee drank and yaf his felawe drynke also
Thorwe wiche a noon they deyde bothe twoo
But certes I suppose that avicen
Wroot nevere in no canovn ne in no fen
Mo wonder sorwes of enpoysonyngge
Thise hadde this wrecches to here Eendyngge .
Thus endede been thise homicidies two
And eke this false enpoysenere also
Oo cursed synne fulle of all cursednesse
Oo Traytouris homisidies Oo wickednesse
Oo glotenye luxurie and hasardrye
Thow blasfemour of Cryst wtith velanye
And oothes greete of vsage and of pride
Allas man kyinde how may it be tyde
That to thy creature wiche that thee wroughtte
And wtith his precious blood hee bowghtte
Thow art soo fals and soo kyinde allas
Now gode men god for yeve yow yowre trespas
And kepe yow froo thee synne of avarice
Myin holy pardoun may yow alle warissche
Soo that yee offre noblis ore starlynggis
Owther ellys selvꝰer sponys brochis or Rynggis
Bowyht yowre heedis vnder this bulle
Comyht vp yee wyvis that offre wolle
Yowre names I enttre into my Rolle heere a noon
In to thee blisse of hevene schulle yee alle goon
I yow assoyle bee myin heye powere
Yee that wole offren as klene and as klere
As yee weren born and loo siris thus I preche
And Ihu Crist that is owre sowlis leeche
Soo gravntte yow his pardoūn to Resseyve
For that is best I wole yow nowt desseyve
But siris Oo word for gate In my talee
I have relykis and pardoun in my malee
As feyre as any man that is in Engellonde
Wyche were yeven by thee popis honde
If eny of yow wole of devocioun
Offren for to haven myin Absolicioun
Comyht foorht A noon and knelyht here adown
That yee may have part of my pardown
Or ellys takyht ꝑperadowne as yee weende
All newe and frechs atte every tounys Eende
Soo that yee offren alwey newe and newe
Noblis and pens that been bothes good and trewe
Hit is an honowre to everich that been here
That yee may have A sufficiant pardonere
Too assoyle yow in cvntree as yee Ryde
For aventuris wyche that may bee tyde
For ꝑperaventure theer may falle oon or twoo
Down of his hors and breke his necke on twoo
Loke wiche assewretee it is to yow alle
That I am in yowre felaschippe I falle
That may assoyle yow bothee more and lasse
Whanne that thee sowle schall froo thee body passe
I Reede that owre Ooste ferst by gynne
For hee is moost envolupte in synne
Come foorht syre Ooste and offre ferst anoon
And thow schalt kesse my Relikys everichon
Yee for a grote vn boukele a noon thy purs
Nay nay quod hee thanne have I crystis curs
Late bee quod hee it schall nowt been so theche
Thow woldest make mee to kysse thyin Oolde breech
And swere hit were thee relike offe a seynt
Thowgh it were wtith thy fundement I peynt
But bee thee Croys wiche seynt Elyne foond
I wolde I hadde thy Coylonis in myin hoond
In stede of relikys ore offe setewarie
Leete cvtte hem of and I wole helpe hem to carye
They scholde been schrinede in an hogges tourde
This ꝑperdonere ansswerde nowght Oo worde
So wrooht hee was hee wolde no thyng saye
Now quod owre Ooste I wole no lengere playe
Wtith thee no wtith noone other angry man
But Ryght a noone thee worthy knyght be gan
Whanne hee sawe that alle thee peple lowgh
Noo more of this for it is Ryght I nowgh
Sire ꝑperdoner bee merie and glad of chere
And yee sire Ooste that been to mee so dere
I praye yow that yee kysse thee ꝑperdonere
And pardoner I preye yow drawe yow neere
And as wee dede lete vs lawghe ⁊ pleye
And a noon they kysseden and rood foorht her weye
¶ Here Eendyht thee ꝐPerdoneris tale
(base) nOw Frendes said ourꝰer oste so dere
(base) How lyketh yow now of this tale here
(base) Ho hath vnbokled well þe male
(base) For he hath us tolde a thryfty tale
(base) As towchyng as myssegouꝰernaunce
(base) Y pꝰery to god yeve hym goode chaunse
(base) As ye haue herde of these riotours thre
(base) Nowe gentel Maryner hertely y paray the
(base) Telle us a goode tale and þtat right anone
(base) Hyt schall be doon by seynt Iohn
(base) Seyd this Maryner as wel as y kan

div.l: (base) And right anone his tale he bygan
and bee gynnyht thee Tale
A Marchavnt whilvm dwellede atte seynt denis
That Riche was for wiche men helde hym wyis
A wyif hee hadde of Exilent beawtee
And cvmpenable and Reverēmtt was schee
Wiche is a thyng that causyht more disspence
Thanne all is worht thee chere and reverence
That men hem done atte feestis and atte dawncis
Swiche salutaciounes and cvntenauncis
That passeht as dooht thee schadewe on a wall
But woo is hym that schal paye for all
Thee sely housebande algate hee mote paye
And hee vs mote bothe clothe and arraye
All for his owne worschipe richely
In wiche array wee dawncen Iolily
And yif that hee may nowght ꝑperaventture
Ore ellis luste noone swiche disspense endure
But thynkyht that it is waste and I lost
Thanne moot Another payen for owre cost
Ore lene vs gold and that is perelus
This noble Marchawnt heeld a noble hous
For wiche hee hadde alday greet repayre
For his largesse and for his wyif was so fayre
That wonder is but herkenyht to my tale
Amongis all his gestis greete and smale
Theer was a Mvnk a feyir man and a boold
I trowe thritty wynter hee was Oold
That evere in oone was drawynge to that place
This yonge Mvnk that soo feyr was of face
Aqueynted was soo wtith that good man
And eke this Mvnk of wiche I bee gan
Weren bothe twoo I borne in one vilage
Thee Mvnk hym claymede as fore cosynage
And hee a yeyne seyde nowght ones nay
But was as glad theer offe as fowl of thee day
For to his hertte it was a greet plesaunce
Thus were they knett wtith eterne aliaunce
And ilke of hem gan other assure
Of bretherede whilys that here lyif may dewre
Free was dan Iohn and namelye of dispence
As in that hows and full of deligence
To doo plesaunce and also greet costage
Hee nowt for gatt to yeve thee leeste page
In alle that hows but after here degree
Hee yaf thee lord and sithenys his meyne
Whanne that hee cam svme honest thyng
For wiche they wer as glad of his comyng
As fowle is fayne whanne thee svnne vp rysiht
Noo more heere offe as now for this sufficeht
¶ But soo by fell this marchavnt on a day
Schope hym to make redy his Array
Towardis thee town offe Bruggis forto fare
For to beyen theere a porcioun of ware
For wiche hee hath to paryis sent a noon
A Messageer and preyd hath dan Iohn
That hee scholde come to seynt denyis to pleye
Wtith hym and wtith his wyif a day or tweye
Ere he to Brugges wentte in alle wyse
This noble Mvnk of wiche I yow devise
Hath of his Abbot as hym leste licence
By cause hee was a man of heygh prudence
And also an Officere owt forto Ryde
Too see here Granges and here bernes wyde
And to seynt denyis hee comyht anoon
Who was soo welcome as my lord dan Iohn
Owre dere Cosyn full of curtesye
And wtith hym hee browghte a Iubbe of Maluiesye
And also another full of fyin vernage
As volatilye as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem Eete and drynke ān pleye
This Marchawnt and this Munke a day or tweye
Thee thridde day this Marchavnt vp a Rsyht
And on his nedys sadly hym a vyseht
And vp into his cowntyng hows gooht hee
Too rekene wtith hym self as wel may bee
Of that ilke yeer how that it wtith hym stode
And how hee hadde disspendid his goode
Or yif that hee en kresed were or noone
His bokis and his baggis manye oone
Hee leyht to fore hym on his cowntynge boorde
Full Riche was his tresour and his hoorde
For wiche ful faste his covntur dore hee schette
And also hee nolde that noo man scholde hym lette
Of his a comptis for thee mene tyme
And thus hee sytte tille it was passed primee
Dan Iohn was risen in thee morwe alsoo
And in thee gardyn walkede twoo and froo
And hath his thyngis seyde full devowtly
This goode wyif come walkyngge full previly
In to thee Gardyn there hee walkede softe
And hym schee salevyht as schee hath doon ofte
A Mayden chyild come in here companye
Swich as here leste that schee may governe ⁊ gye
For yit vnder thee yerde was that Mayde
Oo dere Cosyn myin dan Iohn schee seyde
What eyleht yow soo rathe fore to a ryse
Neece quod hee hit awghtte I nowgh suffice
Fyve Oowris fore to slepe vppon a nyght
But yif it were for an Oolde palled wyght
As been thise wedded men that lye and dare
As in thee fvrme sytttiht a wery hare
Were alle for straught wtith howndis grete ⁊ smale
But dere Nece why been yee soo pale
Fore I trowe certis that owre good man
Hath yow laboured syhtthe thee nyght bee gan
That yow were nede to resten hastily
And wtith that word hee lowgh full merily
And offe his owne thowght hee wax all Reed
This feyre wyif gan to schake hiere heed
And seyde thus yee god woot al quod schee
Nay Cosyn myin it stantte nowt soo wtith mee
For by that god that yaf mee sowle and lyif
In all thee reawme of frawnce is theer no wyif
That lasse lust hath too that sory play
For I may synge allas and weele awey
That I was borne but to noo wyght quod schee
I daar nowt tellen how it stant wtith mee
Wherfore I thenke owt of this lond to wende
Ore ellis of my self for to make an eende
Soo full I am of dreede and eke offe care
This Mvnk by gan vppon this wyif to stare
And seyde alas nay nece god it forbeede
That yee for any sorwe ore for any drede
For doo yowre self but telleht mee yowre greef
For ꝑperaventrure I may in yowre Mescheef
Cvnseyle or helpe and ther fore tellyht it mee
Alle yowre avyis fore it schall bee secre
For on my portos I make heere myin Ooht
That never in my lyve for leef ne for looht
Ne schal I yow of no cvnseyl bee wreye
Thee same a yeen to yow quod schee I seye
By god and by this portos I yow swere
Thowg men mee wolde al into pecis tere
Ne schal I nevere forto goo to helle
Bee wreye a word of thyng that yee mee telle
Nowght for no Cosynage ne noon Alyaunce
But verraly for loue and affiaunce
Thus been they sworne and here vppon kyste
And eche of hem tolde other what hem lyst
¶ Cosyn quod schee yif I hadde space
As I haue noon and namely in this place
Thanne wolde I telle yow a legende of my lyif
What I svffred haue syhtthe I was a wyif
Wtith myn hosebande al thowg he be yowre Cosyn
Nay qd this Mvnk by god and seynt Martyn
Hee ne is no more Cosyn vnto mee
Thanne is this leef that hangyht on the tree
I klepe hym soo by seynt denys of fraunce
For to have thee more cause of a queintaunce
Of yow thee wyche I have lovid speciallye
This swere I yow vppon my professioun
Tellyht yow greefe leste hee a down
And hastyht yow and goht yowre way a noon
My dere loue quod schee Oo my gode dan Iohn
Full leef mee were this cvnseyll forto hyde
But owt it moote it may no lengere abyde
Myin husbande is to mee thee moste worste man
That evere was syhtthe thee world by gan
But syhtthe I am a wyif it sit nowt to mee
Too tellyn no wyght offe owre previtee
Neyther in bedde no in noon other place
God schyilde I scholde telle hit fore his holy garace
A wyif ne schal nowt seye of hiere housbonde
But alle honowre as I can vnderstonde
Saue vnto yow thus mochell telle I schall
As helpe mee god hee is nowght worht at all
In no manere degree thee valewe of a flye
But yit mee grewyht most his nygardye
And weel yee woot that womēmn naturally
Desiren thyngis sixe soo weel as I
They wolden that hiere husbonde schulde bee
Hardy wyis Riche bothe large and free
And buxvm to his wyif and frechs in bedde
But by that ilke lord that fore vs bledde
For his honowr my self to arraye
On soneday nexte I moote paye
An hvndreht frankys ore ellys am I lorn
Yit were mee levere that I hadde been vn born
Thanne me were doon sklavndre or velanye
And eke yif myin housebonde myghtte it asspye
I ne were but lost and ther fore I yow pray
Lene mee this sowme for ellis moot I deye
Dan Iohn I seye lene mee this hundred frankis
ꝐPerde I wole nowt fayle yow my thankys
Yif yow lust to doon that I yow praye
For atte a certeyn day I wole yow paye
doon yow what plesaunce and servise
That yow liste and in what wyse
And but I d god take on mee vengeaunce
As fowle as evere hadde Genilon of fravnce
This gentel Monk ansswerde in this manere
Now trewly myin owne lady dere
I haue quod hee on yow soo great a Rowthe
That I yow swere and plyghte yow my trowthe
That whanne yowre housbande is to flavndres fare
I wole delivere yow owt of this worldis care
I wole yow brynge an hundred of frankys
And wtith that hee cawghtte hiere by thee flankys
And hiere embracede harde and keste hiere ofte
Gooht now yowre qd schee alle stille and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as yee may
For I knowe by my stomak it is prime of day
Gooht now and bee as trewe as I schall bee
Ore ellis god for bede sire seyde schee
And foorht schee gooht as Ioly as a pye
And bad the cokes that they scholde hem heye
Soo that men myghtte dyne and that anoon
And vp to hiere housebande is thys wyif goon
And knockede atte his covntur dore boldely
Que la quod hee peter sire quod sche it am I
Quod schee what how longe wole yee faste
How longe tyme wole yee rekene and caste
Yowre sovmes and bokys and yowre rekenyngis
Thee devell have paarte in alle swiche thyngis
Yee have I nowgh ꝑperde of goddis sonde
Comyht down to day and lete yowre bagges stonde
Bee yee nowght a schamed that dan Iohn
Schall been fastynge al this longe day a goon
Lete vs here masse and goo dyne
Wyif qd this man lytell canst thow devine
Thee corious besinesse that wee have
For vs chapmen so god mee save
And by that lord that klepyd is seynt yve
Skrslye a mongis twenty two vs thryve
Continvally lastynge to owr e
Wee may weel make chere and good visage
And drive foorht thee world as it may bee
And kepe owre esstate in previte
Tille wee bee deed or ellis that wee pleye
A pilgrymage or goon owt of thee weye
And therfore haue I greet necessitee
Vppon this queynte world to a vyse mee
For evere more wee mote stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune in owre chapmanhede
Too flavndres wole I goo to Morwe atte day
And come a yeen assone as evere I may
For wiche my dere wyif I thee bee seche
As bee to every wyght buxum and meke
And forto kepe owre good bee corious
And honeslye governe w owr hows
Thow hast I nowgh in every mane wyse
That to thrifty howshold may suffise
Thee lackyht noone array ne noone vitayle
Of selver in thy purs thow mayst noon fayle
And wtith word his covnter dore hee schette
And down hee gooht no lengere wolde he lette
And hastilye a Masse was there seyd
And smartlye thee tabelis were leyd
And to thee diner faste they hem spedde
And richely this Mvnk thee Chapman fedde
And aftere dinere daun Iohn soberly
And seyde to hym cosyn it stodyht soo
That weel I see to Bruggis wole yee goo
God and seynt avstin spede yow and gyde
I preye yow cosyn while that yee ryde
Gouerne yow also of yowre dyete
Attemꝑperally and namely in this heete
Bytwixe vs two nedyht noo stravnge fare
Fare weel Cosyn god kepe yow fro care
Yif anythyng bee by day ore by nyghte
Yif it lye in my powere or in my myghtte
That yee mee wolde comounde in any wyse
It schal bee doon ryght as yee wole devise
thyng or that yee goon yif it may bee
I wolde preye yow for to lene mee
An hundred frankys for a wyke or tweye
For certeyn beestis that I moste beye
To store wtith a place that is owris
God helpe mee soo I wolde it were yowris
I schall nowt fayle certeynlie of my day
This chapman toke aparte all previly
Nowght for a thowsand frankes ⁊ a Mileway
But leet this thyng bee sekre I yow pray
And god of hevene spede yow on yowre way
And fare weell now myne owne cosyn dere
Graunt Mercy of yowre coste ⁊ of yowre chye
This noble Marchaunt gentilly Anoon
Ansswerde and seyde Oo cosyn daun Iohn
Now sikirly this is a small requeste
My gold is yowres whanne that you leste
But nowght only my gold but my chaffare
Take that yow lyste god schilde that yee spare
But Oo thyng ther is yee knowe it weel I nowgh
Of Chapmen that here money is here plowgh
Wee may creavnce while wee have a name
But goldlees fore to bee hit is no game
Pay it ayen whanne it hiht in yowre Eese
Afte my myght fayn wolde I yow plese
Thee hundred frankis fette hee foorht anoon
And previly hee toke hem to daūnn Iohn
Noo wyght in this worlde wiste of that lone
Saue this marchaunt and daun Iohn hem oone
They drunken and Remen and wenten to pleye
Tille that daun Iohn roode to his Abbeye
¶ Thee Morwen com and thee Marchawnt ridyht
Too flavndris wardis his prentyis well hym gidyht
Vntill hee come to Bruggis merily
Now gooht this Marchaunt faste and busily
A bowte his nedis and byeht and creaunchyt
Hee nowther pleyiht atte thee dyis no dawnchit
But as a Marchavnt schortlye forto telle
Hee ladde his lyif ān there I lete hym dwelle
Thee soneday nexte thee Marchaunt was gon
To seynt denyis comen is daun Iohn
Wtith crowne and beerde freche and newe schave
In all thee hows theer ne was so lytel knave
Ne no wyght ellis that they ne were fayn
For that my lord daun Iohn was comēm agayn
A schortlye to thee poynt fore to goon
This feyre wyif a cordyht to daun Iohn
That fore thise hundred frankis hee schulde alnyght
Haue hiere in his armes bolt vp Ryght
And this a corde parformed was in dede
In merth all nyght a besy lyif they lede
Tille it was day that daun Iohn wentte his way
And bad thee meyne fare weel ān have good day
For none of hem ne noone of hem in thee tovn
Haue to daun Iohn no maner suspeccioun
And forht hee rydiht hoom to his Abbeye
Or where hym leste no more of hym I seye
This Marchaunt whanne endede was the feyre
To seynt denyis hee gan to repeyre
And wtith his wyif hee makyht feeste and chere
And toolde hiere that chaffare was deere
That nedis moste hee make a chevisaunce
For hee was bownde in a Reconisaunce
Too paye twenty thowzand frankys a noon
For wiche this Marchaunt is woned to goon
To borwen of certeyn freendis that hee hadde
A certayn frankys and some wtith hym hee ladde
And whanne hee was comyn in to thee tovn
For greet cherte and greet effeccioun
Vnto daun Iohn ferste hee gooht to pleye
Nowt forto borwe of hym no Moneye
But forto wyte and see of his weel fare
And for to tellen hym of his chaffare
As freendis doon whanne they been mette īn fere
Daun Iohn hym makyht feeste and chere
And hee hym tolde ayeen full specially
That hee hadde sped full weell and graciously
Thanked bee god al hool his Marchavntise
Saue that hee moste in alle maner wyse
Make a chevesaunce as fore his beste
And thanne scholde hee bee in Ioye and reste
Daun Iohn certis I am Ryght fayne
That y hee bee come hoom a gayn
And ywer ryche soo have I blisse
Of y Mt frankis schulde nowght mysse
For yet soo kyndelye this other day
Lentte mee gold and as I can and may
I thanke bee god and by seynt Iame
But natheles I toke vnto owre dame
Yowre wyif att hoome thee same gold a yeen
Vppon yowre benche schee woot it wel certeyn
By certayn tokens that I can hiere telle
But bee yowre leue I may no lengere dwelle
Owre abbot wole owt of this tovn anoon
And in his cvmpanye I moote goon
Gretyht weel owre dame myn owne nece swete
And fare weel dere cosyn till that wee mete
This Marchaunt wtith that was war ⁊ wyis
Creaunced hath and eke payde in paryis
To Certayn lumbardis redy in here handis
This sovme of gold and gate of hem thee handis
And hoom hee gooht as merie as a popeniay
For weel hee knewe hee stoode in swiche array
That nedis moste hee wynne in swiche a viage
A thowsand frankys a bove alle his costage
His wyif full redy mette hym att thee yate
As schee was wonte of Oolde vsage algate
And all that nyght in merthe they were sette
For hee was riche and cleerlye owt of dette
Whanne it was day this Marchaunt gan enbrace
His wyif all newe and kessede hiere in the face
And vp hee gooht a made it wonder towe
Noo more quod sche by god yee have a nowef
And wantownly a yeen wtith hym schee pleyde
Tille att thee laste this Marchaunt seyde
By god quod hee I am a lytell wrooht
Wtith yow my wyif all thowgh it bee mee looht
And woot yee why by god as that I gesse
For yee haue maade a manere of stravngenesse
By twixe mee and my Cosyn daun Iohn
Yee scholde have warned mee or I hadde goon
That hadde yow an hvndred frankys payd
By redy tokene ⁊ hee heeld hym evell payde
For that I to hym spak of a cheuesaunce
Mee semede soo as by his cvntenawnce
But natheles by god that is hevene Kyng
I thowghtte nowght to aske of hym no thyng
But I preye thee wyif ne doo no more soo
Telle mee alwey or that I froo thee goo
Yif eny detorur that hath in myin abcence
I payde thee : leste thorghw thy neclygence
I myghtte hym aske as thyng that hedde payde
This wyif was nowther ferde noo afrayde
But boldely schee seyde and that a noone
Marye I deffye that falce Munk daun Iohn
I kepe nowt of his tokenis nevere a deell
Hee toke mee certeyn gold I wote it weell
What evell thedom on his Mvnkys snowte
